title: Get Started
text: load first dataset (called aart), run chunk . addition loading dataset, looking first rows using head(). dataset two columns, one representing time--event (Xi) another one truncation time (Yi). estimate hazard rate using estimate_hazard() function assign result aart_hazard. carry_hazard replazes 0 hazard estimates last non-zero hazard estimate. function returns data.frame containing time event, respective hazard estimates, standard errors (log scale). also includes lower upper bounds hazard rate confidence interval, correspond confidence level specified ci_level argument. , inspect final rows using tail(): believe don’t need output fh uh columns. think? summary() function returns cleaner output: Finally, can easily visualize results using plot() function:  ggplot2 powered version plot also available, allows visualize multiple levels confidence .  interesting feature package, allows calculating CDF associated time events using hazard function. achieve , suffices call calc_cdf function. function adds column (called cdf) output estimate_hazard function.

title: Get Started
text: Now, show can use almost identical workflow deal analyze right-censored data well. achieve goal, load another dataset, called mbalt. dataset three, opposed two, columns. represent time--event (Zi), left-truncation time (Yi), right-censoring indicator (Di). , estimate hazard rate using estimate_hazard() function time assign result mbalt_hazard. carry_hazard replazes 0 hazard estimates last non-zero hazard estimate. Notice, added extra argument function call: censoring argument, receives indicator variable 1s one event right censored 0 otherwise. output analogous seen previous example, can easily extract summary follows: plotting functions also work box:  ggplot2 powered version plot also available, allows visualize multiple levels confidence .
code: data(mbalt) head(mbalt) #>   Zi Yi Di #> 1 37 29  1 #> 2 30 29  1 #> 3 37 30  1 #> 4 32 32  1 #> 5 37 32  1 #> 6 36 33  1 mbalt_hazard <- estimate_hazard(time_to_event = mbalt$Zi,                                 trunc_time = mbalt$Yi,                                 censoring = mbalt$Di,                                 ci_level = 0.95,                                 carry_hazard = TRUE) ## need summary(mbalt_hazard) #>    time_to_event     hazard se_log_hazard   lower_ci   upper_ci #> 27            31 0.05372423    0.02048953 0.05160948 0.05592563 #> 32            36 0.04244229    0.03464025 0.03965637 0.04542393 plot(mbalt_hazard) ggauto(mbalt_hazard, ci_level = c(.5, .75, .85, .9, .95))

title: Get Started
text: Lastly, show estimate_hazard() function features deal competing risks. showcase features, load aloans dataset. dataset contain information consumer automobile loans (Jackson P. Lautier, Pozdnyakov, Yan 2024). check columns represent, take look dataset documentation running help(aloans). relevant columns dataset example following: Z: time event Y: left-truncation C: right censoring indicator D: Default indicator (1 represents default, 0 represents pre-payment) two competing risks case default pre-payment. create informative column distinguish two events. package designed workflow identical previous two examples. output analogous seen previous example, now additional column specifing event type. plotting functions work previous examples:  ggplot2 powered version plot also available:

title: Calculate Default Time Points — calc_tp
text: helper function generates default sequence evaluation points based study's overall time range (Lautier et al. 2023, <DOI: 10.1016/j.ecosta.2023.05.005>). particular, calculates \(\Delta\) \(m\) based left-truncation time--event variables outputs sequence ranging \(\Delta + 1\) \(\omega\).

title: Calculate Default Time Points — calc_tp
text: time_to_event vector event censoring times. trunc_time vector left-truncation times.

title: Calculate Default Time Points — calc_tp
text: numeric vector default time points evaluate hazard .

title: Auxiliary function for estimate_hazard — .hazard_core
text: Auxiliary function estimate_hazard

title: Auxiliary function for estimate_hazard — .hazard_core
code: .hazard_core(   support,   trunc_time,   time_to_event,   censoring,   event_indicator,   carry_hazard )

title: Auxiliary function for estimate_hazard — .hazard_core
text: support calculate hazards trunc_time numeric vector representing observed left-truncated time. time_to_event numeric vector representing observed time event. censoring indicator censoring (1=censored, 0=). Defaults vector 0s NULL. observation treated event status=1 censoring=0. event_indicator legacy. carry_hazard boolean indicator whether 0 hazard estimates replaced last non-zero estimate. Defaults FALSE

title: Auxiliary function for estimate_hazard — .hazard_core
text: data.frame

title: Auxiliary function for estimate_hazard — .hazard_core
text: lcgodoy

title: Hazard rate — estimate_hazard
text: Estimate non-parametric hazard rate truncated censored data

title: Hazard rate — estimate_hazard
code: estimate_hazard(   time_to_event,   trunc_time = NULL,   censoring = NULL,   event_type = NULL,   support_lifetime_rv = NULL,   carry_hazard = FALSE,   ci_level = 0.95 )

title: Hazard rate — estimate_hazard
text: time_to_event numeric vector representing observed time event. trunc_time numeric vector representing observed left-truncated time. censoring indicator censoring (1=censored, 0=). Defaults vector 0s NULL. observation treated event status=1 censoring=0. event_type vector "events identifies" (experimental) support_lifetime_rv vector time points evaluate hazard.  NULL (default), calculated sequence Delta + 1 omega (, max(time_to_event)). carry_hazard boolean indicator whether 0 hazard estimates replaced last non-zero estimate. Defaults FALSE ci_level number 0 1 indicating level confidence intervals.

title: Hazard rate — estimate_hazard
text: data.frame hazard estimate standard errors asymptotic confidence intervals.

title: Hazard rate — estimate_hazard
text: Point estimate asymptotic confidence intervals calculated based  (can also include brief notation/definitions )

text: x data.frame required columns 'alife' object. Defaults empty data.frame.

text: object class alife.

title: Create an alife Object — new_alife
code: # Create a minimal data frame with the required columns df <- data.frame(time_to_event = 1:2, fh = c(.2, .01), uh = c(.8, .20),                  hazard = c(0.1, 0.125), se_log_hazard = c(0.1, 0.1),                  lower_ci = c(0.08, 0.1), upper_ci = c(0.12, 0.15))  # Construct the alife object my_alife_obj <- new_alife(df) class(my_alife_obj) #> [1] "alife"      "data.frame"

title: abslife 0.0.94
text: Logo included package website README file. First draft vignette. Two new datasets: aart (left-truncation) mbalt (left-truncation + right-censoring). event_indicator longer argument estimate_hazard().

title: abslife 0.0.93
text: ggplot2 included suggested package fixed “check” number events estimate_hazard broken smaller functions make easier mantain. Included summary function alife objects Extended plot function deal multiple event types rlang becomes dependency :( autoplot method making graphs ggplot2

title: abslife 0.0.92
text: Fixed competing risks approach.

title: abslife 0.0.91
text: event_type parameter estimate_hazard function now deals competing risks. single_t_hazard internal function created. meant make code easier debug expliting big estimate_hazard function self-contained chunks. ci_level now parameter estimate_hazard function. First draft estimate_hazard function. far, competing risks implemented. calc_tp helper calculates \(\Delta\) \(m\) based left-truncation time--event variables outputs sequence ranging \(\Delta + 1\) \(\Delta + m\). Create class alife enable plot method estimate_hazard function output. Function carry hazard estimates forward “zero hazard” observed.

title: abslife 0.0.9
text: dataset aloans included far.
